item.title: Comment on Earning Your Backstory by Ian Small
item.dc:creator: Ian Small
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2019/02/19/earning-your-backstory/#comment-2">Daniel J. Bishop</a>.
Completely agreed. I love DCC of course, and it's my go to for introducing new players to my game or "breaking in" certain groups. I also love 5e for being so solid, flexible and respectful of my/the players time, so I love to blend them together.
I do agree that if you took EVERYTHING from DCC to play 5e you might as well just play DCC, but it is fun to mix and match to come up with your own homebrew game. Sometimes I like to say "this area runs on DCC rules X, Y and Z because things are weird and out of control here" just to ramp up the feeling of chaos in an area of my world.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Daniel J. Bishop.

Completely agreed. I love DCC of course, and it’s my go to for introducing new players to my game or “breaking in” certain groups. I also love 5e for being so solid, flexible and respectful of my/the players time, so I love to blend them together.

I do agree that if you took EVERYTHING from DCC to play 5e you might as well just play DCC, but it is fun to mix and match to come up with your own homebrew game. Sometimes I like to say “this area runs on DCC rules X, Y and Z because things are weird and out of control here” just to ramp up the feeling of chaos in an area of my world.

item.title: Comment on Earning Your Backstory by Daniel J. Bishop
item.dc:creator: Daniel J. Bishop
item.description: If you really wanted to go this route, the DM could just write a custom Occupations table using the racial mix they want to see in their campaign. Or ignore the race component on the main occupation table and also roll for race. You could have a whole series of "how to use this cool bit from DCC in 5e" if you wanted to. There are a LOT of cool bits. But just playing DCC is probably a better solution.
item.content:encoded:
If you really wanted to go this route, the DM could just write a custom Occupations table using the racial mix they want to see in their campaign. Or ignore the race component on the main occupation table and also roll for race.
You could have a whole series of “how to use this cool bit from DCC in 5e” if you wanted to. There are a LOT of cool bits.
But just playing DCC is probably a better solution.
